choices.C: Write an ACL to block the IP address of www.malwaresite.com at the gateway firewall.
choices.D: Use an IDS custom signature to create an alert for connections to www.malwaresite.com.
choices.B: Reconfigure the enterprise antivirus to push more frequent to the clients.
choices.A: Configure the company proxy server to deny connections to www.malwaresite.com.

discussion.content: This is tricky. Question only asks for a way to monitor for the same malware in the future - then D should be the answer. But if they want to prevent this kind of malware infection from happening again, then A is the best choice. Letter C won't block all connections of malwaresite if the IP address changes in the future.

comments.content: My guts are telling me to go with D on this one. They're asking for the BEST way to monitor it, right? Not the MOST SECURE way to deal with it. Maybe another control is set in place (like a Sinkhole) and the analyst just wants be notified about activity related to the ransomware strain? In which case D would be better, because it includes alerting.

discussion.content: I feel it's A because proxy servers can monitor and control

A - Remediation action makes it A. On a proxy dashboard, you should still be able to see real-time traffic to that domain but it won't show alerts.
D - Using an IDS custom signature to create alert for connections to the malicious site is better for monitoring since you get alerts upon connections

Therefore, D is the best answer
Based on the word “monitor”, I agree it has to be A.... here’s where we have to hope we think the same as the test maker....
I thought D because it said 'monitor'!!! otherwise A

choices.B: Open port 3389 on the firewall to the server to allow users to connect remotely.
choices.C: Set up a jump box for all help desk personnel to remotely access system resources.
choices.D: Use the company's existing web server for remote access and configure over port 8080.
choices.A: Configure a VPN concentrator to terminate in the DMZ to allow help desk personnel access to resources.

discussion.content: Jumpbox is for admin use basically, like a proxy before the main box or server as the case may be, A is more likely the correct answer imo

comments.content: Can you explain why you feel it's A?

discussion.content: Jumpbox is usually for Admin use...

I had the same answer. Its awesome that you got into the DMZ but your still locked out by the internal firewall. C is a better choice as you have a jump box for the in between. Only issue i can think of is how many users connecting to the jump box and can it handle that type of load...

comments.content: Nope. Only open up port and ip relevant to the vpn concentrator

discussion.content: I think C is a better choice? Letter A says that the vpn concentrator will terminate at the dmz, then what happens? Users will still go to internal network to access resources? This opens up more security risks since we will need to open more connections from dmz to internal.

questions.question_text: A company allows employees to work remotely. The security administration is configuring services that will allow remote help desk personnel to work secure outside the company's headquarters. Which of the following presents the BEST solution to meet this goal?

discussion.content: https://nmap.org/book/scan-methods-ack-scan.html

questions.question_text: A security administrator recently deployed a virtual honeynet. The honeynet is not protected by the company's firewall, while all production networks are protected by a stateful firewall. Which of the following would BEST allow an external penetration tester to determine which one is the honeynet's network?

discussion.content: Another question where it would be nice to have more info. A if the assessment is internal, b if external. Based on what we have I assume the analyst is internal. So A would be correct.
which controls prevent any value? In other words what is of no use...

Key point is "Which of the following compensating controls"

A or B : Detailed and tested firewall rules seems compensating control for SCADA, So i choose B
This question was on the exam (october-2020)
I believe B I'd more of outside the network, while A is within the network.

comments.content: ACL is the same as firewall rules

discussion.content: ACL is more on which users to allow and which not. So its set at the OS level vs firewall is much earlier in the chain. thoughts?
I think A is a better choice. B is already incorporated on letter A with additional network segmentation.

questions.question_text: A security analyst is conducting a vulnerability assessment of older SCADA devices on the corporate network. Which of the following compensating controls is likely to prevent the scans from providing value?

choices.B: Detailed and tested firewall rules that effectively prevent outside access of the SCADA devices.
choices.A: Access control list network segmentation that prevents access to the SCADA devices inside the network.
choices.C: Implementation of a VLAN that allows all devices on the network to see all SCADA devices on the network.

questions.question_text:
A logistics company's vulnerability scan identifies the following vulnerabilities on Internet-facing devices in the DMZ:
✑ SQL injection on an infrequently used web server that provides files to vendors
✑ SSL/TLS not used for a website that contains promotional information
The scan also shows the following vulnerabilities on internal resources:
✑ Microsoft Office Remote Code Execution on test server for a human resources system
✑ TLS downgrade vulnerability on a server in a development network
In order of risk, which of the following should be patched FIRST?

discussion.content: i think vul that related to remote execution that is the very high severity and need immediate action
RCE is always prioritised over other vulnerabilities.
RCE is always the most critical no matter what. It also has the highest payout in bug bounties

comments.content: Also, the additional detail for the remote code answer, this is on a Human Resources server... meaning PII is in jeopardy. Definitely A.

Thers is the word there test server, nt actual production server, but the point is we dont know if the test server is connected to the network, but on a second tot, RCE implies it is connected and can be accessed remotely imo

On second thought, files that are provided to vendor contain very little data, or no sensitive data at all. While if the attacker has exploited the vulnerability in the test server which is located in the internal network, he is already inside the internal network, and can try many ways to pivot to production servers. He is already close to sensitive data unlike letter B.

discussion.content:
Isn't letter B way riskier than letter A?
SQL injection on an internet facing web-server that provides files to the vendors, compared to an internal server which has microsoft office RCE. There are much more controls/security tools which will mitigate/prevent the vulnerability from being exploited on internal resources compared to the ones located in the DMZ.
